newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Telekom net seen up 14-18 pct.
newsitem.headline: Telekom net seen up 14-18 pct.

text.p: Net earnings at state-run telecommunications firm Telekom Malaysia Bhd are expected to rise between 14 percent and 18 percent for 1996, analysts said on Tuesday.
They said Telekom should post earnings of around 1.8 billion ringgit to 1.85 billion ringgit ($725.8 million to $746 million) for calendar 1996, up from 1.575 billion ringgit in 1995.
"There're not going to be any surprises. It should be within market expectations," said a telecommunications analyst at a European brokerage.
A Telekom official said the company was expected to report year-end results this week.
Analysts said higher revenues from local and long-distance domestic calls -- which make up about 50 percent of turnover -- will underpin earnings.

"If you are looking at the bottom line per se and nothing else, it won't deviate much from the consensus," said Haizan Khir Johari, analyst at Schroder Research. "But I heard there could be slight disappointment in one or two aspects of the business."
The consensus forecast of analysts in the Estimate Directory puts Telekom's net profit at 1.85 billion, or 92.5 cents a share.
Analysts said for the ongoing financial year, the immediate concerns for Telekom come from worries about competition in the local market.

Other Malaysian telecommunications players have been calling for an earlier start to industry liberalisation, while Telekom's newly launched mobile phone service has arrived in an already overcrowded market.

Telekom's stock has been under pressure in recent weeks, due partly to concerns that the government would bring forward an earlier start to "equal access". This would let Telekom's three million subscribers use the networks of other fixed-line operators to make international calls.
But analysts said recent official comments suggested the industry would not be ready for equal access before the original starting date of January 1, 1999.
The government has awarded fixed-line licences to Time Engineering Bhd's telecommunications unit, Technology Resources Industries Bhd, Mutiara Telecommunications Sdn Bhd and Binariang Sdn Bhd.
"The feeling is that all operators must be prepared. But by the time that happens, it will be near the end of 1998," said a research head at a Malaysian brokerage.
Analysts said issues such as interconnection costs and sharing of revenue have yet to be resolved.

Telekom's recently launched mobile phone service, called TMTouch, will take time to make money in the highly competitive market. There are six other mobile service operators and they all have a big head start over Telekom, analysts said.
"It takes time for them to break even, maybe two to three years," said the Malaysian brokerage's research head.
